coredata.dc:title: Vibrational relaxation of HCl in HCl/liquid xenon mixtures
coredata.dc:creator: Knudtson, J.Thomas
Weitz, Eric
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The vibrational relaxation of HCl in liquid xenon at −68°C has been studied. Vibrationally excited HCl is created following UV photolysis of HCl. The rate of relaxation of HCl as a function of HCl mole fraction in liquid xenon is the same as the corresponding rate for gas phase HCl at −68°C. Similarly the rate of relaxation of HCl in HClXe collisions is in good agreement with the corresponding gas phase rate. These observations imply that the isolated binary collision model is valid for this system.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 104, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 VIBRATIONAL RELAXATION OF HC1 IN HC1/LIQUID XENON MIXTURES J. Thomas KNUDTSON + Department ofCftemistry. Northern Illinois University, DeKalb. Illinois 60115, USA and EricWEITZ* Department of Chemistry, Northwestern University, Evanston. Illinois 60201. USA Received 20 October 1983 The vibrational relaxation ofHCl in liquid xenon at 68 C has been studied. Vibrationally excited HC1 is created following UV photolysis of HC1. The rate of relaxation of HC1 as a function of HC1 mole fraction in liquid xenon is the same as the corresponding rate for gas phase HC1 at 68 C. Similarly the rate of relaxation of HC1 in HCl Xe collisions is in good agree- ment with the corresponding gas phase rate. These observations imply that the isolated binary collision model is valid for this system. 1. Introduction Vibrational energy transfer studies in the gas phase have received a great deal of attention in the last few decades [1,2]. More recently energy transfer investiga- tions in liquids have been of interest. Experimental and theoretical advances in this area have been recently re- viewed [3]. A fundamental question in these studies is the nature of dynamical processes leading to relaxa- tion. Much of the work has been in neat and dilute mixtures of cryogenic diatomic liquids. Non-radiative energy transfer in these systems has been successfully interpreted in terms of an isolated binary collision (IBC) model [3 6]. Of particular interest to the result reported here are the treatments of rets. [4 6] which utilize the IBC model in the interpretation of their re- sults on a number of diatomic cryogenic liquid sys- tems. We report the results of an investigation of the vibrational relaxation behavior of HC1 in liquid Xe; a polar molecule in a polarizable liquid, and interpret it in light of the IBC model. We also report on a method of generating vibrationally excited HC1 in liquid rare * Work performed at Northwestern University. * Alfred P. Sloan Fellow 1978-1982. 0 009-2614/84/S 03.00 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) gases which may have extensions to a variety of other appropriate sysiems. 2. Experiment The experimental apparatus is shown in fig- 1. A Lambda Physik excimer laser operating on ArF at 193 nm was used for excitation. At 1 Hz repetition rate the average energy per pulse was typically 30 40 mJ. An aperture immediately in front of the sample cell reduced the beam diameter to 3 8 mm and the single pulse energy to 1 6 mJ. The high-pressure, low-tem- perature cell was similar to that of Beatie et al. [7]. The cell was a copper block with two perpendicular holes drilled to form a cross. The inner portion was gold coated to prevent chemical attack by the HC1- The ex- citation windows were quartz and the detection win- dows were sapphire. All were sealed with indium gas- kets. The inner cell was supported in a larger chamber with corresponding quartz and sapphire windows to form a dewar. Two thermocouples at the top and bot- tom of the cell were used for temperature measure- ments. Using a Neriab refrigerated cooler the cell could be cooled to 68 C. At this temperature the vapor 71 Volume 104,-riumber 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 Excimer Loser ArF 193 nm -S i Filter ln:Sb detector low temperature " cell 1 ^t-" Refrigerator Fig. 1. Schematic of the experimental apparatus. pressure of liquid xenon is 95 psi. Infrared emission was viewed perpendicular to the excimer beam with an InSb detector followed by a variable gain 1 MHz bandwidth pre-amplifier. The sig- nal was digitized by a Biomation 8100 transient record- er and averaged when necessary by a Nicolet 1170. The response time of the detection system was ^^SO ns. Three different infrared filters were used: a narrow- band interference filter with 50% transmission points of 3.398 to 3.599 pm, a 3 4 fm broad band interfer- ence filter and an OCU circular variable filter. The cir- cular variable filter has a minimum bandpass with a fwhm of =30 cm"1 for a one degree slit. The full width at 5% for this configuration is 40 cm"1. A monel high-pressure vacuum line was used to make the liquid xenon HC1 mixtures. After the cold cell was filled with Air Products Electronic grade HC1 and the pressure measured with a Baratron capacitance manometer, the cell was valved off from the monel system. The monel system was then pressurized to as 125 psi with Cryogenic Rare Gases Research grade xenon (>99.995%). The xenon was admitted to the cell in bursts until the cell was filled with liquid. Dur- ing fulling the turbulence was more than adequate to mix the solution. Mole ratios were calculated using the density of liquid xenon at -68 C and 95 psi [8]. The density .of the HC1 was corrected for the difference in temperature of the capacitance manometer (295 K) and the cold cell (205 K). A rough estimate of HC1 193 nm absorption was made by placing a Scientech laser power meter after the cell. At 25 ton- of HC1 the excimer laser was atten- uated by about 50%. Since the path length was 3.8 cm this yields an absorption coefficient of 3.2 X 10~3 cm"1 Torr~1 (base 10), which is in reasonable agree- ment with previous results [9]. 3. Results 3.1. Absorption and emission spectra Fig. 2 shows both the absorption and emission spectra of a dilute liquid xenon/HCl mixture at 205 K. The absorption spectrum of the 1 X 10-4 HCl/Xe mole ratio sample obtained with a Nicolet Fourier trans- form spectrometer at 1 cm"1 resolution. It has a liquid- xenon-induced Q branch, which has been reported previously [10], centered between the expected Pand R branches. The emission spectrum was taken with an OCU cir- cular variable filterwith a one degree slit. The frequency resolution was approximately 30 cm~l. This filter and slit combination significantly reduced the amount of 72 Volume 104, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 Fig. 2. Superposition of the absorption and emission spectrum of HC1 in liquid Xe at 205 K. The right-hand ordinate indicates the absorbance for a 1 X I0~4 mole fraction mixture of HC1 in liquid Xe- The absorption spectrum (solid line) was obtained with a FTIR spectrometer of 1 cm"1 resolution. The left-hand ordinate indicates the relative emission intensity (solid line with data points) following photolysis of the above mixture. Error bars show both the wavelength and amplitude uncertainty of a typical measure- ment. radiation reaching the detector. As a result each point on the spectrum was obtained by averaging 512 laser shots. At the peak of the spectmm the signal/noise was approximately 5:1. The vertical error bar on one point (2700 cm""1) in the emission spectrum in fig. 2 represents an estimated uncertainty derived from sev- eral averages at the same frequency. The apparent differences between the absorption and emission profiles are partly due to the low resolu- tion of the circular variable filter and the low signal/ noise of the measurement. However, significant dif- ferences in absorption and emission profiles are to be expected. For a gas phase sample the relative line strengths, S^, of transitions in the P and R branches can be cal- culated as follows [11]: S^ = ^ m exp(-EJ/KT) QJ-1 F(m). (1) Sy is the vibrational band strength, m is the line num- ber (for the P branch m = Jjower an^ t^ ^ branch m = -/jo^er + l)i ^J ls t^ie rotational energy of the ab- sorbing or emitting molecule. QJ is the rotational par- tition function and F(m) is the vibration rotation interaction correction which varies slowly with m so that it can be ignored for this calculation. In absorp- tion at 205 K, spectra generated via eq. (1) show the peak of the R branch will absorb about 30% more strongly than the P branch, and in emission the P branch will be about 30% stronger than the R branch. Although the liquid environment does significantly perturb the absorption spectrum, mainly through the presence of the Q branch, the R branch can be seen to absorb more strongly than the P branch. Therefore, we may expect the P branch to be stronger in emission than the R branch. In fig. 2, the peak of the emission spec- trum is indeed at the P branch frequency (2800 cm"1). The anharmonicity in the HC1 u = 2 -> v = 1 transi- tion is about 100 cm~1. The emission spectrum in fig. 2 does not show any clear indication of 2 - -1 emission such as a peak or a shoulder to the red of the P branch 73 Volume 104, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 emission. However, if the population ofu=2 was of the order of 15% or less than the v = 1 population, the low resolution and low S/N of the emission spectrum could mask it. 3.2. Energy transfer rates The time dependence of the infrared emission from HC1 was observed in both the gas and liquid samples. Fig. 3a shows the decay curve for a 50.54 Ton- sample of pure gas phase HC1. The rise time is detector limited. Fig. 3b shows the corresponding decay curve when liquid xenon is condensed into the cell along with HC1 (mole fraction HCl/Xe = 2 X 10-4)- Note the scale of the abscissa decreases by a factor of five from fig. 3a to fig. 3b. The risetime in fig. 3b is near detec- tor limited. The signal amplitude increased by a factor of 6 with the addition of liquid xenon. This is not ob- Mole Rotio HCl/Xe (xlO'*) 1.96 3.92 5.68 7.B4 SJSO T1.76 Fig. 3. (a) Trace of a typical signal following photolysis of 50.54 Ton of gas phase HC1 at 205 K. (b) Trace of typical signal following photolysis ofa2x 10'4 mole fraction mix- ture of HC1 in liquid Xe at 205 K. 100 150 ZOO ZSO 300 350 HC1 Pressure (Torr) Fig. 4. HC1 vibrational relaxation rate at 205 K in the gas phase ( ) and in liquid xenon ( ). The lower abscissa refers to the gas phase data while the upper abscissa refers to data for HCl/liquid Xe solutions. vious in fig. 3 because of the difference in number of shots averaged (50 for fig. 3a and 30 for fig. 3b), am- plifier gain and signal averager parameters. However, the higher SfN of the liquid xenon mixtures is appar- ent. Fig. 4 illustrates the vibrational relaxation rate of neat gaseous HC1 and HC1 in liquid xenon as a func- tion of HC1 concentration at 68 C. All relaxation signals were analyzed as single exponentials. The slope of the line indicating the rate of relaxation of gas phase HC1 as a function of pressure is (1.96 0.08) X 1010 cm3/mole s (1.55 ms-1 Torr-1), in good agree- ment with the gas phase relaxation rate reported at 205 K [12]. The relaxation rate as a function of HC1 concentration in liquid xenon is (1.8 03) X 10t0 cir^/niole s in excellent agreement with the gas phase result. Since the mixtures are very dilute in HC1, the xenon mole fraction can be considered constant. Thus, the intercept in fig. 4 represents the vibrational relaxa- tion rate due to HC1* xenon collisions. This rate is 155 30ms-1. 4. Discussion 4.1. Vibrational energy transfer Delalande and Gale have developed a very useful model for vibrational relaxation in fluids at liquid densities [5]. They have shown their model gives 74 Volume 104, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 good agreement with experimental vibration transla- tion/rotation (V T/R) rates for H^, D^ and H^/Ar and D^/Ar mixtures. In their model of a pure system, the energy transfer rate T~^ depends on the two-body rate constant kQ(T), the density p, and the radial pair distribution function g(p, T; o), T-^p^r.tOW), kQ(T) depends only on temperature and for an ideal gas where g(p, T; a) = 1, it is the relaxation rate con- stant. The variation of the relaxation rate with density is entirely contained in the pg(p, T; o) product. Delalande and Gale have extended their model to the case of mixtures. The result is that the rate T~1 depends on the sum of two terms just like eq. (1) weighted by the mole fractions of the components. For the liquid xenon HC1 system, one term represents the HCl Xe relaxation rate and the other represents the HC1 HC1 relaxation rate. Turning first to the HC1-HC1 term, ky(T) is simply the gas phase HC1 HC1 rate shown in fig. 4. The fact that liquid Xe/HCl mixtures have the same HC1 density dependence (slope) as gas phase samples means that g(p, T, o) is the same in both phases. This is not sur- prising since HC1 densities are low, well within the re- gion where only two body effects are important. Chesnoy and Ricard [6] have recently reported the vibrational relaxation rate in both high-density and neat-liquid HC1. Measured rates were faster than the extrapolated low-density rate ofZittel and Moore [12] by about a factor of three. They attributed the increase to a relaxation mechanism involving HC1 van derWaals dimers. Dimers are expected to start to effect the relaxation rate at densities of about one atmosphere. Since the HC1 densities in the HCl xenon mixtures are well below one atmosphere, van der Waals dimers are not expected to influence the relaxation rates in this study. To apply eq. (1) to the HCl Xe relaxation rate given by the intercept in fig- 4, we need the gas phase relax- ation rate and the density dependence of the liquid HCl Xe relaxation rate. The gas phase rate has not been reported. In addition we were not able to measure the density dependence of the HCI Xe rate because our sample preparation system was not capable of handl- ing the higher pressures associated with higher densi- ties at 205 K. Although we do not have sufficient in- formation to interpret the HCl Xe rate in terms of eq. (1) we can use the simpler cell model (13] which preceded the Delalande Gale model. The relaxation rate in the cell model is the product of a relaxation probability. PV-T/R ^rom gss phass data and a liquid collision frequency Ky^, T~l'!XPV-TfRKmy.- The collision frequency can be calculated from the Lenard-Jones hard-sphere diameter cr, the average ve- locity 17, and the density p, ^=u/(pl/3-o). Forp= 1.22 X 1022 cm-3 and crna-Xe^ 3-16 A t14!- the collision frequency is 5.2 X 1012 s-t. This gives a probability of relaxation of 3 X 10-8 per HC1 Xe col- lision. The probability for relaxation in HCl Ar collisions at room temperature is 1.7 X 10~8 [ 15]. A vibrational rotation (V -* R) relaxation mechanism is known to be important in the relaxation of gas phase HC1. This mechanism is particularly operative and dominant for HC1 HC1 and HCi-heavy rare gas collisions [16]. A similar relaxation mechanism in the liquid is plausible. For a V -> R relaxation machanism. for rare gas colli- sion partners of mass greater than or equal to argon, the expected dependence of the relaxation probability on the reduced mass of the collision partners is very weak [15,17]- The observed temperature dependence for argon relaxation is also weak and a similar weak temperature dependence would be expected for HC1 Xe collisions [15,17]. Thus the probability of relaxa- tion for HCl Xe collisions at 68 C can be taken as approximately equal to the HC1 AT relaxation proba- bility at room temperature- With these assumptions, the measured relaxation probability in liquid xenon is in good agreement with the expected gas phase relaxa- tion probability. 4.2. Excitation mechanism The mechanism of HC1 excitation following HC1 photolysis represents an interesting question. The likely possibilities involve an initial atom atom re- combination step to produce HC1*. H^, or CH (where * represents a vibrationally excited molecule) or trans- lation to vibration (T V) energy transfer to HC1 from translationally hot H atoms. T V energy transfer from translationally hot hy- 75 Volume 104, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 drogen atoms generated via ArF photolysis ofHCl has _ been shown to vibrationally excite a.variety of molec- ular systems [18 20]. Thus it is likely that HC1 excita- tion in gas phase samples results from T V energy transfer- T V might also seem like an attractive mech- anism to explain the observed vibrationally excited HC1 in liquid Xe- However, in our system photolysis occurs in liquid Xe where mole ratios ofXe/HCl 3" 10^. Thus on the average a hydrogen atom will en- counter 1000 Xe atoms per encounter with an HC1 molecule. H atoms from ArF photolysis of HC1 are produced with 1.84 eV of translational energy [18 20]. Though it is not known with what efficiency a hot H atom will excite HC1 as a function ofH atom velocity, it is clear that the minimum translational energy necessary to excite HC1 is equal to the energy of an HC1 vibration. The HQ v= 1 transition in li- quid Xe is at about 0.36 eV. The loss ofH atom trans- lational velocity per collision with a Xe atom can be approximately calculated by the formula [21] fractional energy lost = 2 m^m^/(m^ + Wg)2 , where m^ and my are the H and Xe masses. Thus the energy lost per collision is 1.5%. The number of col- lisions that result in a decline in translational energy to below 036 eV can also be calculated and is 109 collisions. For a H atom to retain enough translational energy to excite an HC1 molecule to u = 1 it would have to suffer <109 collisions before ah encounter with an HC1 molecule while; the average molecule suffered 1000 collisions per encounter with a HC1 molecule- Assuming collisional events can be described via a Polsson distribution, in a 1/1000 mole ratio system, only == 10% of all H atoms will encounter a HC1 before its energy dropped below threshold. Single-shot signal to noise of20: 1 is observed in HCl/Xe mixtures as dilute as 4 X 10~5 mole fraction HC1. In this system, only = 3 X 10-3 of the H atoms will encounter an HC1 before deactivation to below threshold energy. 2 X 10~4 of the HC1 molecules in the sample are photolized as calculated from the atten- uation of the ArF laser beam. Thus a maximum of 3 X 1011 excited HC1 molecules/cm3 can be produced via T - -.V transfer. A simple signal-to-noise calcula- tion shows this number is lower than what would be expected for the observed signal/noise but within an order of magnitude of the expected figure ^. However, in reality 3 X 10.11 excited HC1 molecules/cm3 repre- sents an upper limit since it is certain that more trans- lational energy than the minimum is required for effi- cient excitation ofHCi (u = 1). Additionally, the effi- ciency forT-*- V transfer is known to drop off as transla- tional velocity decreases [19]. An important addi- tional piece of information is at low HC1 concentra- tions (<10 Torr), a non-detector-limited rise time is observed for the HC1 signals in liquid Xe. This implies the average HC1 molecule appears in the u = 1 level on a timescale longer than s500 ns. On this timescale, the average H atom has encountered 2.6 X 106 Xe atoms and its velocity is completely thermalized. It could be pustulated that T -> V transfer occurs on a shorter timescale and is followed by V V transfer with V V transfer equilibrating the vibrational distribution. This is very unlikely because this would necessitate T -> V transfer primarily to higher levels than u = 1 which puts a more stringent requirement on the ve- locity of an H atom and thus makes it a much less likely process. The conclusion from this data is that T V transfer cannot be luled out as a source of some excited HC1, however it appears to be unlikely that it is a major source of excited HC1 in liquid HQ/Xe mixture. Other possible sources of HC1 excitation involve reactions of atoms generated in the photolysis of HC1. Relevant reactions include H+Cl+Xe^HCF+Xe, H+H+Xe-^H^+Xe. H+HCl-^-H^+Cl, Cl + Cl + Xe -> d$ + Xe. (I) (U) (III) (IV) Reaction (II) could be followed by energy transfer to HC1 via H2(u = n) + HC1(0) -r HaO? = n - 1) + HCl(u = 1) as could reaction (III) if it were sufficiently exother- mic to produce H$. Since the exothennicity of reac- tion (III) is only 0.047 eV [9] it can be ruled out as being involved in the production of vibrationally ex- cited HC1. Reaction (IV) is also unlikely as the source of vibrationally excited HC1. Even ifCli were efficient- * For example, a calculation can be performed based on the procedure in ref. [22]. 76 Volume 104, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 ly produced via recombination, transfer ofvibrational energy to HC1 would require a multiple-quantum pro- cess and would be expected to be inefficient [1]. Thus reactions (I) and (II) remain to be considered. The re- ported room temperature rate constant for reaction (II) is ==8 X 10-33 cm6 molecule-2 s-1 which repre- sents an average value for a variety of third bodies [23]. For a Xe density of 1.22 X 1022 molecules/cm3 and dissociation of2X 10~4 of HC1 molecules, this gives a rate of reaction of ^7 X 10^7 molecules/cm3 s at 1 Torr HC1 pressure. This would represent a half-life of 50 PS, calculated at the initial reaction rate; far slower than the observed rise rate at this mole fraction of ^500 ns. Though reaction (II) might be expected to have a negative activation energy, it would be expected to be small making it very unlikely that the low tem- perature of the liquid xenon could cause a significant increase in reaction rate relative to the observed two orders of magnitude discrepancy. In addition, forma- tion of H$ would have to be followed by energy trans- fer to HC1 which could only make this mechanism more unlikely. The rate constant for reaction (I) is less well known with reported numbers that vary from 2.3 X 10-30 to 7.0 X 10-33 cm6 molecule-2 s-1 at 205 K [24]. The lower limit of these numbers gives a rate of production of HC1 which is also incompatible with the observed HC1 risetime at low pressure- The upper limit gives a half-life of approximately 400 ns, compatible with what we observe. The observation of emission from only u = 1 then implies that V -> V transfer is faster or of comparable time with respect to the predicted rate of production ofvibrationally excited HC1 via reaction (I). This is also incompatible with reported values for gas phase HC1 V V processes [25]. Based on existing data and the above calculations, at present we favor the mechanism of eq. (1) as the source of most of the excited HC1 in liquid Xe with possible contributions from T -* V processes. As a caveat, it should be realized that all numbers that were used in the calculations are gas phase numbers that are being used in a liquid environment. It is also clear that the method of HC1* production warrants further experimental study to definitively determine its pro- duction mechanism. 5. Conclusions The vibrational relaxation rate of HC1 dilute in liquid xenon solutions has been measured as a function of concentration. The HC1 density dependence of the energy transfer rate is the same in xenon solutions as in gas phase xenon; 1.96 X 1010 cm^/mole s (1.55 ms-1 Torr~^). This result is in good agreement with a number of models of condensed phase relaxation. The number of xenon collisions per second has been calculated using the cell model. For this number and the observed relaxation time, the probability of re- laxation per HCl-Xe collision of3X10-8 has been calculated. This number is in good agreement with ex- pectations based on published gas phase HCl Ar data. Vibrationally excited HC1 was generated following photolysis of HC1 in xenon. The possible sources of HC1 vibrational excitation in the gas and liquid phases are discussed- In the liquid phase it seems most likely that excitation of HC1 results from a three body re- combination ofH+Cl with Xe as the third body. Oxford, 1977). {31 D.W. Oxtoby, Ann. Rev. Phys. Chem. 32 (1981) 27; A. Laubereau and W. Kaiser, Rev. Mod- Phys. 50 (1978) 607. (4] W-F. Calaway and G- Ewina. J. Chem. Phys. 63 (1975) 2842;Chem. Phys. Letters 30 (1975) 485; S.RJ. Brueck and R-M. Ossood. Chem. Phys- Letters 39(1975)568. 77 Volume 104, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 January 1984 (5] C. Delalande and G.M. Gale, J. Chem. Phys. 71 (1979) 4804; 73 (1980) 1918; Chem. Phys. Letters 71 (1980) 264; P. Roussignol, C. Delalande and G.M. Gale, Chem. Phys. 70(1982)319; M: Chateau, C. Delalande, R. Frey, G.M. Gale and F. Pradere,J. Chem. Phys. 71 (1979) 4799. [6] J- Chesnoy and D. Ricard. Chem. Phys. 67 (1982) 347; . Chem. Phys. Letters 91 (1982) 130. [7] W.H. Beatie.W-B. Maier II, R.F. Holland, SM. Freund and B. Stewart, SPIE report on Laser Spectroscopy 158 (1978)113. [8] F. Theeuwes and RJ. Beannan, J. Chem. Thennodyn. 2 (1970)501. [9] H. Okabe, Photochemistry of small molecules (Wiley, New York 1978). [10] J. Kwok and G.W. Robinson, J. Chem. Phys. 36 (1962) 3137. 111) W.S. Benedict, R. Herman, G-E. Moore and S. Silvennan, 1. Chem. Phys. 26 (1957) 1671. [12] P.F. Zittel and C.B. Moore, J. Chem. Phys. 59 (1973) 6636. [13] W.M. Madigosky and TA. Litovits, J. Chem. Phys. 34 (1961)489. (14] J.O. Hirschfelder. C.F. Curtiss and R.B. [17] E.WeitzandG.W.Flynn,J:Chem.Phys. 58(1973) 2679. [18] F. Magnolia, D.J. Nesbitt and S.R. Leone, Chem. Phys. Letters 83 (1981) 21. [19] CA. Wight and S.R. Leone, J. Chem. Phys. 78 (1983) 4875. [20] C.R. Quick It.. R.E. Weston Jr. and G.W. Flynn, Chem. Phys. Letters 83 (1981) 15. [21] R.M. Martin and J.E. Willard, J. Chem. Phys. 40 (1964) 3007. [22] E. Weitz, Ph.D. Thesis, Columbia University (1972). [23] D.W. Trainor. D.O. Ham and F. Kaufman, J. Chem. Phys. 58 (1973) 4599. [24] E.S. Fishburne, J. Chem. Phys. 45 (1966) 4053; T-A. Jacobs, N. Cohen and R.R. Giedt, J. Chem. Phys. 46 (1967) 1958; D.J. Seery and C.T. Bowman, J. Chem. Phys. 48 (1968) 4314; W-D. Breshears and P.F. Bird, J. Chem. Phys. 56 (1972) 5347. [25] S.R. Leone, J. Phys. Chem. Ref. Data 11 (1982) 953. 78 ts pro- duction mechanism. 5. Conclusions The vibrational relaxation rate of HC1 dilute in liquid xenon solutions has been measured as a function of concentration. The HC1 density dependence of the energy transfer rate is the same in xenon solutions as in gas phase xenon; 1.96 X 1010 cm^/mole s (1.55 ms-1 Torr~^). This result is in good agreement with a number of models of condensed phase relaxation. The number of xenon collisions per second has been calculated using the cell model. For this number and the observed relaxation time, the probability of re- laxation per HCl-Xe collision of3X10-8 has been calculated. This number is in good agreement with ex- pectations based on published gas phase HCl Ar data. Vibrationally excited HC1 was generated following photolysis of HC1 in xenon. The possible sources of HC1 vibrational excitation in the gas and liquid phases are discussed- In the liquid phase it seems most likely that excitation of HC1 results from a three body re- combination ofH+Cl with Xe as the third body. head.ce:title: Vibrational relaxation of HCl in HCl/liquid xenon mixtures

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The vibrational relaxation of HCl in liquid xenon at −68°C has been studied. Vibrationally excited HCl is created following UV photolysis of HCl. The rate of relaxation of HCl as a function of HCl mole fraction in liquid xenon is the same as the corresponding rate for gas phase HCl at −68°C. Similarly the rate of relaxation of HCl in HClXe collisions is in good agreement with the corresponding gas phase rate. These observations imply that the isolated binary collision model is valid for this system.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Vibrational and rotational relaxation in gases
Molecular theory of gases and liquids
